If there is the fetter of craving on this matter, is there also the fetter of anger?
Such chapters and the meaning of the chapters
having already been understood,
one should next extensively explain.
Herein, the matter
there are five kinds of matters.
First, the matter of the intrinsic nature.
Second, the matter of the object.
Third, the matter of bondage.
Fourth, the matter of cause.
Fifth, the matter of inclusion.
As for the matter of the intrinsic nature,
it is as explained in the aggregate of views.
If a matter can penetrate it, can that matter be completely known?

If a matter can be completely known, can that matter be penetrated? He speaks of the matter of the intrinsic nature of the various forbearances and knowledges with the word matter. He further says, if a matter is already attained, is that matter accomplished?
If a matter is accomplished, is that matter already attained?
Regarding this, some say:
The essence of all dharmas is referred to by the word thing.
Some say:
If a dharma has attainment, it is referred to by the word thing.
The object-referent thing refers to:
As the Prakaraá¹‡a states:
All dharmas are to be known by cognition according to their object-referents.
What is meant by according to their object-referents?
It means that if a dharma is the object-domain of a certain cognition,
it is referred to by the word thing in relation to that [cognition].
However, the sÅ«tra states:
I will explain to you the forty-four things of cognition and the seventy-seven things of cognition.
The Abhidharma masters say:
That sÅ«tra refers to the essence-things.
It means that the things that are the objects of the various acceptances and cognitions are referred to by the word thing.
The Venerable SubhÅ«ti states:
That sÅ«tra refers to the object-referent things.
It means that the things that are the objects of the various acceptances and cognitions are referred to by the word thing.
The bound thing refers to:
As it is explained here:
If there is a fetter of craving with regard to this matter, is there also a fetter of hatred?
And so on, explaining in detail.
Here, the five categories of dharmas are referred to by the word matter.
That is to say, dharmas that are eliminated by seeing suffering, the origin, cessation, and the path, and by cultivation.
Because they are bound by the afflictions of these five categories, they are called bound matters.
As for matters of causes,
it is as explained in the Abhidharma-nyÄyÃ¢nusÄra-Å›Ästra.
What are matters with substance?
What are matters without substance?
Their meaning is to speak of dharmas with causes and dharmas without causes.
Moreover, the GÄthÄ says:
The bhiká¹£u's mind is tranquil, able to permanently eliminate all matters.
Because his birth and death are exhausted, he does not accept future existence.
The meaning of this verse is as follows:
All birth and death depend on causes.
Because there are causes, there is birth and death.
Because the causes are severed, birth and death are exhausted.
Because of this, he does not again accept the three existences of future birth. As for matters of grasping,
it is as explained in the sÅ«tras.
One should abandon the mind of grasping matters of fields, houses, and wealth.
One should avoid affairs of fields, affairs of houses, affairs of wealth, and the activities of acceptance.
Moreover, the GÄthÄ says:
If one has affairs of fields, wealth, cattle, horses, and servants,
Men, women, relatives, and desires, one is called extremely greedy.
Moreover, laypeople say:
I accept this matter, I uphold this matter.
These are called the affairs of acceptance.
There are also five matters:
First, the matter of realms;
Second, the matter of places;
Third, the matter of aggregates;
Fourth, the matter of the world;
Fifth, the matter of moments.
Among these ten matters,
Here, the treatise is only based on the matter of bondage,
Not based on the other nine.
The Abhidharma scholars say:
The bound matter is real, and the actual bonds are also real.
The pudgala is provisional.
The VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«yas say:ğŸ”½The bound matter is real,
And the actual bonds are also real.
The pudgala is also real.
The UpÄyakauÅ›alyas say that the bonds are real,
The object of attachment is also a provisional person.
Question: Why do they say that the object of attachment is provisional?
Answer: They say that being defiled and being undefiled are not determined with respect to objects, therefore one should know that objects are not real.
It is like a certain beautiful woman who, adorned in various ways, enters an assembly.
Some who see her give rise to respect, some who see her give rise to desire,
some who see her give rise to anger,
some who see her give rise to jealousy,
some who see her give rise to disgust, some who see her give rise to compassion,
some who see her give rise to equanimity.
One should know that in this case the son who sees her gives rise to respect.ğŸ”½Those who indulge in desire see her and give rise to desire.
Those who are her enemies see her and give rise to anger.
Those who are her husband's equals see her and give rise to jealousy.
Those who cultivate the contemplation of impurity see her and give rise to disgust.
Those who are detached from desire see her with compassion.
Thinking like this:
This wonderful form will soon be destroyed by impermanence.
Arhats see her and give rise to equanimity.
Therefore, we know that objects have no real substance.
Their explanation is unreasonable.
Why is it so?
If objects are not real,
they should not be conditions giving rise to mind and mental factors.
If that is so, then there should be no defiled or pure dharmas.
The pudgala definitely does not really exist.
Because the Buddha said there is no self and nothing belonging to a self.
There are afflictions associated with the five consciousnesses,
and there are those associated with mental consciousness.
As for those associated with the five consciousnesses,
if they are in the past, they bind past events.ğŸ”½If they are in the present, they bind present events.
If they are in the future and are subject to birth, they bind future events.
If they are not subject to birth, they bind events of the three times.
As for those associated with mental consciousness,
whether they are in the past, future, or present,
they all bind events of the three times.
Furthermore, afflictions associated with eye consciousness bind form as an object.
They bind the associated mental faculty and dharma faculties as associated bonds.
The afflictions associated with the ear consciousness form a bond of object-support in relation to the sound realm.
In relation to the associated mental realm and dharma realm, they form a bond of association.
The afflictions associated with the nose consciousness form a bond of object-support in relation to the smell realm.
In relation to the associated mental realm and dharma realm, they form a bond of association.
The afflictions associated with the tongue consciousness form a bond of object-support in relation to the taste realm.
In relation to the associated mental realm and dharma realm, they form a bond of association.
The afflictions associated with the body consciousness form a bond of object-support in relation to the touch realm.

In relation to the associated mental realm and dharma realm, they form a bond of association. The afflictions associated with the mental consciousness form a bond of object-support in relation to the twelve realms.
In relation to the associated mental realm and dharma realm, they form a bond of association.
This is called a brief exposition in one line.
If there is bondage of the fetter of craving in this matter, is there also bondage of the fetter of hatred?
Answer: If there is bondage of the fetter of hatred in this matter, there must be bondage of the fetter of craving.
There may be bondage of the fetter of craving without bondage of the fetter of hatred.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
It means that the fetter of craving for form and formless realm dharmas has not yet been severed.
Here, the fetter of craving pervades the three realms and the five categories.
It only has impure objects and is not universal.
The fetter of anger is only in the desire realm and pervades the five categories.
It only has impure objects and is not universal.
Those who are fully bound, with regard to the five categories of dharmas in the desire realm,
if there is the fetter of craving, there is also the fetter of anger.
If there is the fetter of anger, there is also the fetter of craving.
With regard to the five categories of dharmas in the form and formless realms,
there is the fetter of craving but not the fetter of anger.
Those who are not fully bound, with regard to the five categories of dharmas in the desire realm,
wherever the fetter of craving has not yet been severed, there is the fetter of craving.
There is also the fetter of anger.
Where it has already been severed, there is no fetter of craving.
There is also no fetter of anger.
With regard to the five categories of dharmas in the form and formless realms,
wherever the fetter of craving has not yet been severed, there is the fetter of craving.
There is no fetter of anger.
Where it has already been severed, there is no fetter of craving.
There is also no fetter of anger.
Because the fetter of craving is long and the fetter of anger is short.
The question should be answered in accordance with the latter phrase.
If there is the fetter of anger on a certain thing, there must be the fetter of craving.
It refers to the things of the five categories in the desire realm that have not yet been completely eliminated.
There may be the fetter of craving,
but not the fetter of anger.
It refers to the dharmas of the form and formless realms where the fetter of craving has not yet been eliminated.
Here, there may be eight stages that have not yet been eliminated,
up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception that has not yet been eliminated.
Within this stage, there may be five categories that have not yet been eliminated,
up to the eliminated by cultivation that has not yet been eliminated.
Within this category, there may be nine grades that have not yet been eliminated,
up to the lowest grade that has not yet been eliminated.
Here, the general characteristic of not yet eliminated is spoken of.
Why are the dharmas of the five categories in the form and formless realms not bound by the fetter of anger?
Because the upper two realms are without the fetter of anger.
Why are the upper two realms without the fetter of anger?
Answer: Because they are not vessels for the fetter of anger.
Moreover, yogis are disgusted with the fetter of anger and seek the two upper realms.
If the two upper realms had the fetter of anger,
yogis would not seek them and diligently cultivate added effort.
If a dharma exists in the lower realm, it also exists in the upper realm.
Then there would be no gradual cessation of dharmas.
If this does not exist, there would also be no ultimate cessation of dharmas.
Because it is what is brought.
If one also denies the ultimate cessation, then one would also deny liberation and emancipation.
To avoid this error, the two upper realms do not have the fetter of anger.
Moreover, the fetter of anger necessarily relies on a coarse and rough continuum.
The continuum of the form and formless realms is subtle and smooth, nourished by superior samÄdhi, and therefore does not have the fetter of anger.
Moreover, if in this realm there is the faculty of sorrow and suffering, then there is the fetter of anger.
Because various sentient beings, relying on the faculty of sorrow and suffering, give rise to anger towards the continuum of others.
Because the realms of form and of the formless are devoid of the faculties of sorrow and suffering, there is no fetter of indignation.
Moreover, if in the realm of desire there were no shamelessness and disregard, there would be the fetter of indignation.
Because sentient beings rely on shamelessness and disregard to generate anger in the life-stream of others.
The two upper realms are devoid of shamelessness and disregard, and therefore there is no fetter of indignation.
Moreover, if in this realm there were envy and stinginess, there would be the fetter of indignation.
Because sentient beings rely on envy and stinginess to generate anger in the life-stream of others.
The realms of form and of the formless are devoid of envy and stinginess, and therefore there is no fetter of indignation.
Moreover, if in this realm there were the faculties of female and male, there would be the fetter of indignation.
Because sentient beings rely on the faculties of female and male to generate anger in the life-stream of others.
The realms of form and of the formless are devoid of the faculties of female and male, and therefore there is no fetter of indignation.
Moreover, if in this realm there were craving for material food, there would be the fetter of indignation.
Because sentient beings rely on craving for material food to generate anger in the life-stream of others.
Because there is no craving for coarse food in the form and formless realms, there is no fetter of anger.
Moreover, if there is sexual desire in a realm, then there is the fetter of anger.
Because sentient beings, relying on sexual desire, give rise to anger towards the life-continuum of others.
Because there is no sexual desire in the form and formless realms, there is no fetter of anger.
Moreover, if there are the five hindrances in a realm, then there is the fetter of anger.
Because sentient beings, relying on the five hindrances, give rise to anger towards the life-continuum of others.
Because there are no five hindrances in the form and formless realms, there is no fetter of anger.
Moreover, if there are the five objects of desire in a realm, then there is the fetter of anger.
Because sentient beings, relying on the five objects of desire, give rise to anger.
Because there are no five objects of desire in the form and formless realms, there is no fetter of anger.
Moreover, if there are objects of hatred in a realm, then there is the fetter of anger.
As for objects of hatred,
they refer to the nine grounds for resentment.
Because there are no objects of hatred in the form and formless realms, there is no fetter of anger.
Therefore the Venerable Vasumitra said:
If sentient beings encounter the characteristics of enemies and those they dislike, they give rise to the fetter of anger.
The characteristics of enemies and those they dislike do not exist in the two upper realms, therefore there is no fetter of anger.
Furthermore, loving-kindness is the proximate antidote to the fetter of anger.
Since there is loving-kindness in the form realm, there is no fetter of anger.
Just as where there is a wind called fierce
there clouds and mist cannot remain.
Since there is none in the form realm, there is also none in the formless realm.
It is not that the afflictions are absent in the lower realms but exist in the upper realms, because they are gradually eliminated.
If there is bondage of the fetter of craving to this thing, is there also bondage of the fetter of pride?
The answer is: so.
If there is bondage of the fetter of pride, is there also bondage of the fetter of craving?
The answer is: so.
This is because the fetters of craving and pride both pervade the three realms and five categories.
They only have contaminated objects as their objects, not the universal ones, because they are long and short, etc.
The question should be answered in this way:
If one is completely bound,
the things of the three realms and five categories are all bound by the two fetters.
Those who are not bound by all fetters,
according to the places they have already severed, are not bound by two fetters.
If they have not yet severed [a place], they are bound by two fetters.
There may be nine stages, up to or there may be one stage. Within this stage, there may be five categories, up to or there may be one category.
Within this category, there may be nine grades, up to or there may be one grade.
Therefore it is said to be like this.
If there is the fetter of craving with regard to a certain thing, is there also the fetter of ignorance?
The answer is: If there is the fetter of craving with regard to a certain thing, there must be the fetter of ignorance. There may be the fetter of ignorance without the fetter of craving.
Namely, when the knowledge of suffering has arisen but the knowledge of accumulation has not yet arisen,
with regard to dharmas to be severed by the knowledge of suffering,
there is the fetter of ignorance to be severed by the knowledge of accumulation that has not yet been severed.
Here, the fetter of craving is common to the three realms and five categories.
It only has impure objects and is not universal.
The fetter of ignorance is common to the three realms and five categories.
It has impure and pure objects, and is both universal and not universal.
Those who are bound by all bonds, in the five categories of things in the three realms,ğŸ”½if there is the bond of craving, there is also the bond of ignorance.
If there is the bond of ignorance, there is also the bond of craving.
Those who are not bound by all bonds, in the places that have already been severed,
may have the bond of universal ignorance but not the bond of craving.
The bond of ignorance is long,
while the bond of craving is short.

The question should be answered in accordance with the preceding statement, that is, in the five categories of things in the three realms, if there is the bond of craving, there must be the bond of ignorance.
There may be the bond of ignorance but not the bond of craving.
The detailed explanation is as before.
That is, when the knowledge of suffering has arisen but the knowledge of the cause has not yet arisen,
the bonds of craving and ignorance that are to be eliminated by seeing suffering,
have already been completely severed in one's own category of things.
Therefore, both are unable to bind.
The universal bond of ignorance that is to be eliminated by seeing the cause, in regard to the things to be eliminated by seeing suffering,
binds as an object.
The bond of craving that is to be eliminated by seeing the cause, in regard to the things to be eliminated by seeing suffering,
Because it is not bound by the object-support, nor is it bound by the universal [contaminants].
It is not bound by association.
Because it belongs to another aggregate.
If there is bondage by the fetter of craving with regard to a certain object, is there also bondage by the fetter of views?
The answer should be given in four sentences.
Here, the fetter of craving is common to the three realms and the five categories.
It only has impure objects and is not universal.
The fetter of views is common to the three realms and only the four categories. It is common to both impure and pure objects and is both universal and not universal.
Those who are fully bound with fetters, with regard to the objects of the three realms and the five categories,
if there is bondage by the fetter of craving, there is also bondage by the fetter of views.
If there is bondage by the fetter of views, there is also bondage by the fetter of craving.
Those who are not fully bound, because the fetter of craving is common to the five categories, is longer.
Because it only has impure objects and is not universal, it is shorter.
Because the fetter of views is only the four categories, it is shorter.
Because it is common to both impure and pure objects and is both universal and not universal, it is longer. Because these two have the meaning of being longer and shorter,
the question should be answered in four sentences.
There may be bondage by the fetter of craving but not by the fetter of views.
That is, when the knowledge of accumulation has already arisen but the knowledge of cessation has not yet arisen.
In the dharmas not associated with the view-fetters to be eliminated by the path of seeing cessation and the path,
and in the dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation, the fetter of craving has not yet been eliminated.
Here, the dharmas not associated with the view-fetters to be eliminated by the path of seeing cessation and the path are:

The essence of those wrong views, and the aggregates associated with and not associated with the views of grasping, the views of precepts and vows, doubt, craving, hatred, pride, and unique ignorance.
Because craving has not yet been eliminated in these dharmas,
there is the fetter of craving.
In one's own aggregates, it is the fetter of the object and the fetter of association.
If in another's aggregates, it is the fetter of the object.
There is no fetter of view.
Why is it so?
Because the pervasive view-fetters that take the five categories as objects have already been eliminated.
The remaining ones that have not yet been eliminated are in the dharmas not associated with the view-fetters.
They are not the fetter of the object.
Because they take the undefiled as their object.
They are not the fetter of association.
Because they belong to another aggregate.
Because the nature of the two is not mutually related.
Because the love bond that has not yet been eliminated with regard to dharmas eliminated by cultivation is still present.
Or there may be love bonds of nine stages that have not yet been eliminated.
Up to or there may be love bonds of one stage that have not yet been eliminated.
Within this stage, there may be love bonds of nine grades that have not yet been eliminated.

Up to or there may be love bonds of one grade that have not yet been eliminated. There is no view bond that is bound, because the all-pervading view bonds that take the five categories as objects have already been eliminated.
Because there are no view bonds eliminated by cultivation.
Next, when the knowledge of cessation has already arisen but the knowledge of the path has not yet arisen,
with regard to dharmas not associated with the view bonds eliminated by the path of insight,
and with regard to dharmas eliminated by cultivation,
the love bond that has not yet been eliminated is still present.
Among them, dharmas not associated with the view bonds eliminated by the path of insight are as explained above.
With regard to these dharmas and dharmas eliminated by cultivation,
the love bond is bound but the view bond is not bound, also as explained above.
Furthermore, the World-Honored One's disciples who have attained full insight have not yet eliminated the attachment to existence that is eliminated during cultivation.
Here, the knowledge of the path has already arisen, and they are fully enlightened about the four noble truths of the three realms, so they are called those with full insight.
They have not yet eliminated the attachment to existence regarding the dharmas eliminated during cultivation.
There may be nine levels of attachment to existence that have not yet been eliminated, up to there being one level of attachment to existence that has not yet been eliminated.

Within this level, there may be nine grades of attachment to existence that have not yet been eliminated, up to there being one grade of attachment to existence that has not yet been eliminated. There is no attachment to views that binds them.
Why is this?
Because all attachments to views have already been eliminated by them.
There may be those who are bound by attachments to views but not by attachments to existence.
This refers to those for whom the knowledge of suffering has arisen but the knowledge of accumulation has not yet arisen.
Regarding the dharmas eliminated by seeing suffering, there are attachments to views eliminated by seeing accumulation that have not yet been eliminated.
Here, the knowledge of suffering has already arisen but the knowledge of accumulation has not yet arisen.
The two, attachments to existence and attachments to views, eliminated by seeing suffering, have both already been eliminated.
Because the attachments to views eliminated by seeing accumulation have not yet been eliminated.
As objects to be abandoned by insight into suffering, they are bound by the fetter of craving.
Although the fetter of craving abandoned by insight into the origin is not yet eliminated, with regard to dharmas abandoned by insight into suffering,
it is not bound as an object, because it is not a universal.
It is not bound as an associated [dharma],
because it belongs to a different group.
There are those bound by both.
Those with complete bonds are bound by two fetters with regard to dharmas abandoned by insight and cultivation.
Why is it called complete bonds?
Because this sentient being is bound by all parts,
and all parts are bound,
it is called complete bonds.
As for bound by all parts,
the five classes of afflictions are all able to bind.
As for all parts are bound,
all dharmas of the five classes are bound.
This one with complete bonds is bound by one part of the fetter of craving with regard to dharmas abandoned by insight into suffering, and by two parts of the fetter of views.
It is the same with regard to dharmas abandoned by insight into the origin.
With regard to dharmas associated with the fetter of views abandoned by insight into cessation,
There is one part bound by the fetter of craving and three parts bound by the fetter of view.
With regard to dharmas not associated with the fetter of view, there is one part bound by the fetter of craving and three parts bound by the fetter of view.
The same applies to dharmas to be eliminated by the path of seeing.
With regard to dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation, there is one part bound by the fetter of craving and two parts bound by the fetter of view.
Next, when the knowledge of suffering has arisen but the knowledge of accumulation has not yet arisen,
there are two fetters binding with regard to dharmas to be eliminated by the path of seeing, cessation, and the path, and by cultivation.
Among them, with regard to dharmas to be eliminated by the path of seeing the accumulation,
there is one part bound by the fetter of craving and one part bound by the fetter of view.
With regard to dharmas associated with the fetter of view to be eliminated by the path of seeing cessation,
there is one part bound by the fetter of craving and two parts bound by the fetter of view.
With regard to dharmas not associated with the fetter of view,
there is one part bound by the fetter of craving and one part bound by the fetter of view.
The same applies to dharmas to be eliminated by the path of seeing the path.
With regard to dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation, there is one part bound by the fetter of craving and one part bound by the fetter of view.
At that time, with regard to dharmas to be eliminated by the path of seeing suffering,
Although there is the fetter of view, there is no fetter of craving.
Therefore this is not mentioned.
Next, when the knowledge of accumulation has arisen but the knowledge of cessation has not yet arisen,
with regard to dharmas associated with the fetter of view that are to be eliminated by the path of cessation and the path of vision, there are two fetters.
Here, with regard to dharmas associated with the fetter of view that are to be eliminated by the path of cessation and the path of vision,
each has one part of the fetter of craving and one part of the fetter of view.

At that time, with regard to dharmas not associated with the fetter of view that are to be eliminated by the path of cessation and the path of vision, and with regard to dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation,
although there is the fetter of craving, there is no fetter of view.
Therefore this is not mentioned.
Next, when the knowledge of cessation has arisen but the knowledge of the path has not yet arisen,
with regard to dharmas associated with the fetter of view that are to be eliminated by the path of vision, there are two fetters.
Here, with regard to dharmas associated with the fetter of view that are to be eliminated by the path of vision,
there is one part of the fetter of craving and one part of the fetter of view.
At that time, with regard to dharmas not associated with the fetter of view that are to be eliminated by the path of vision, and with regard to dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation,
Although there is the fetter of craving, there is no fetter of view.
Therefore, this is not mentioned.
Or there may be no binding of both.
That is, when the knowledge of the truth of origination has arisen but the knowledge of the truth of cessation has not yet arisen,
there is no binding of two fetters to dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing the truths of suffering and origination.
When the knowledge of the truth of cessation has arisen but the knowledge of the truth of the path has not yet arisen,
there is no binding of two fetters to dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing the truths of suffering, origination, and cessation.
The World-Honored One's disciples who have complete [understanding of the] truths have no binding of two fetters to dharmas to be eliminated by [the path of] seeing.
Those who have already become free from the defilements of the desire realm have no binding of two fetters to dharmas of the desire realm.
Those who have already become free from the defilements of the form realm have no binding of two fetters to dharmas of the desire and form realms.
Those who have already become free from the defilements of the formless realm have no binding of two fetters to dharmas of the three realms.
Here, the dharmas that bind and those that are bound have both been eliminated, so they are all free from two fetters.
This is because the fetters of craving and view are both eliminated.
This should also be formulated as questions and answers.ğŸ”½Are there any dharmas associated with the fetter of view that are eliminated by [the path of] seeing cessation and the path,
to which the fetter of craving is bound but the fetter of view is not?
Is it not the case that the latent afflictions do not increase in what is seen?
The answer is: there is.
That is, after severing the six types of fetters, one enters the correct state of renunciation.
The knowledge of the accumulation has already arisen, but the knowledge of cessation has not yet arisen.
The dharmas associated with the six types of fetters to be eliminated by seeing cessation and the path have the fetter of craving.
Because the three types of fetters to be eliminated by seeing cessation and the path are the objects of the fetter of craving that have not yet been eliminated.
Because the universal fetter of views that takes the five categories as objects has already been eliminated.
Because the fetter of views that takes the pure dharmas of one's own category as objects of the first six types has also already been eliminated.

Although the fetter of views that takes the pure dharmas of one's own category of the last three types as objects has not yet been eliminated, it is not the object-pervading fetter of the dharmas associated with the fetter of views that has already been eliminated in the first six types, because it takes the pure dharmas as objects, and it is not the associated-pervading fetter.
Because it belongs to another group.
But the latent afflictions of views do increase.
Because the last three types of the fetters of attachment to views and attachment to precepts and vows of one's own category still increase in the first six types.
The latent afflictions of views are common to the five views.
Because the fetter of views is only the first three views.
It is the same as the case of the fetter of views.
The case of the fetter of doubt is also like this.
That is to say, just as the fetter of views extends to the three realms and is only of four categories,
it has both contaminated and uncontaminated objects, and is both omnipresent and not omnipresent.
The fetter of doubt is also like this.
Therefore, if the fetter of craving is compared to the fetter of doubt, it is the same as comparing it to the fetter of views.
If there is bondage by the fetter of craving with regard to a certain thing, is there also bondage by the fetter of grasping?
The answer is: Four sentences should be made.
Here, the fetter of craving extends to the three realms and is of five categories, only having contaminated objects and is not omnipresent.
The fetter of grasping extends to the three realms and is only of four categories, having contaminated objects,
and is both omnipresent and not omnipresent.
Those who are fully bound with fetters, with regard to things in the three realms and five categories,
if there is bondage by the fetter of craving, there is also bondage by the fetter of grasping.
If there is bondage by the fetter of grasping,
there is also bondage by the fetter of craving. Those who are not fully bound have craving that extends to five categories, so it is longer,

Because these two have the meaning of being long and short in relation to each other, the question should be answered in four sentences.
